position.marginalia_text: M. Antonius Columna, pra[e]clarissimus Iuuenis, post paterna[m] Etrusco bello mortem; Prospero Patruo, et Fabritio huius patrueli, celeberrimis Ducibus adha[e]sit: ab hisq[ue] certissimis militia[e] pra[e]ceptis imbutus, [iiii[r]: ità exactam hausit disciplinam, atq[ue] peritiam, Vt Prosperi, natura cunctatoris, cautum, et inuictu[m] robur; Fabritij verò pra[e]seruida[m] in expediendis armis vim; nobili, salubriq[ue] temperamento moderari didicerit. Jouius, [9.5.] Elog. Bellicoru[m]. Sub Effigie M. Antonij Columna[e]: Ite[m], sub Effigie Prosperi Col. Both Prospero, & Fabritio Colonna, learnid [their] militar doctrine, & discipline, Vnder Don Consaluus Ferrandus, Dux Magnus.]

marginalia.translation:
Marcantonio Colonna, a most distinguished young man, after the death of his father in the Etruscan war, kept close to his paternal uncle Prosperus, and his cousin Fabrizio, most celebrated dukes: and having learned from these men the most certain principles of war, [iiii[r]: thus he took in their combined discipline and experience, such that he learned to control, with a noble and healthy moderation, the guarded and insurpassable might of Prospero (by nature a cautious person), and the the strength of Fabrizio (truly most hotblooded in settling disputes with arms).
Giovio, in Book 9, Chapter 5 of his Elogia Bellicorum. Under the portait of Marco Antonio Colonna: likewise, under the potrait of Prospero Colonna.
Both Prospero and Fabrizio Colonna learned the military doctrine and discipline under Don Consalvo Ferrando, a great leader.]
